sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

For the following independent cases, determine whether economic income is present and, if so, whether it must be included in gross income (i.e., is it realized and recognized for tax purposes?). (Leave no answers blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
a. Asia owns stock that is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, and this year the stock increased in value by $20,000.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: a. Economic income of $20,000 is present, but there is no realization for tax purposes. Without realization, there can be no recognition. Hence this will not be included in the gross income.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
b. Ben sold stock for $10,000 and paid a sales commission of $250. Ben purchased the stock several years ago for $4,000.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. Economic income is present and has been realized through the sale. Return of capital limits the addition to gross income to the net gain on the sale, $5,750. The presumption in the law is that realized income is included in gross income. Thus, absent some additional facts which allow the deferral or exclusion of the income, recognition would follow realization, and the income would be taxed.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
c. Bessie is a partner in SULU Enterprises LLC. This year SULU reported that Bessie’s share of rental income was $2,700 and her share of municipal interest was $750.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: c. Bessie’s share of rental income ($2,700) is included in gross income, and her share of municipal interest ($750) is excluded from her gross income.

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: a. Economic income of ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} is present, but there is no realization for tax purposes. Without realization, there can be no recognition. Hence this will not be included in the gross income.

b. Ben sold stock for ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} and paid a sales commission of $[a(3)]. Ben purchased the stock several years ago for ${{[a(4)]:#,###}}.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. Economic income is present and has been realized through the sale. Return of capital limits the addition to gross income to the net gain on the sale, ${{[a(8)]:#,###}}. The presumption in the law is that realized income is included in gross income. Thus, absent some additional facts which allow the deferral or exclusion of the income, recognition would follow realization, and the income would be taxed.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income

    __new__

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value: No, § 305(a) states that dividends paid in stock are generally not included in gross income. If, however, the taxpayer has the option to receive the dividend in cash (instead of stock), the dividend is included in gross income.

multipleChoice.stem: Devon owns 1,000 shares of stock worth $10,000. This year he received 200 additional shares of this stock from a stock dividend. His 1,200 shares are now worth $12,500. Must Devon include the dividend paid in stock in income?
multipleChoice.commonFeedback: No, § 305(a) states that dividends paid in stock are generally not included in gross income. If, however, the taxpayer has the option to receive the dividend in cash (instead of stock), the dividend is included in gross income.

choice.distractor: No, dividends paid in stock are generally not included in gross income.
Yes, dividends paid in stock are generally included in gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

XYZ declared a $1 per share dividend on August 15. The date of record for the dividend was September 1 (the stock began selling ex-dividend on September 2). The dividend was paid on September 10. Ellis is a cash-method taxpayer. Determine the economic income and the amount he must include in gross income under the following independent circumstances.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
a. Ellis bought 100 shares of XYZ stock on August 1 for $21 per share. Ellis received a $100 dividend on September 10. Ellis still owns the shares at year-end.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: a. Ellis has $100 of economic income and includes the $100 dividend in gross income.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
b. Ellis bought 100 shares of XYZ stock on August 1 for $21 per share. Ellis sold his XYZ shares on September 5 for $23 per share. Ellis received the $100 dividend on September 10 (note that even though Ellis didn’t own the stock on September 10, he still received the dividend because he was the shareholder on the record date).

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. Ellis has $200 of income from the sale of the stock ($2,300 − $2,100) that is included in gross income. Ellis also has $100 of income from the dividend, which he also includes in gross income [See Reg. §1.61-9(c).].

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
c. Ellis bought 100 shares of XYZ stock for $22 per share on August 20. Ellis received the $100 dividend on September 10. Ellis still owns the shares at year-end.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: c. Ellis owns the XYZ shares on the record date, and received the $100 dividend. Hence, Ellis is taxed on the entire dividend. [See Reg. §1.61-9(c).]

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

Ellis received the $[a(4)] dividend on September 10 (note that even though Ellis didn’t own the stock on September 10, he still received the dividend because he was the shareholder on the record date).

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. Ellis has $[a(8)] of income from the sale of the stock (${{[a(10)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(11)]:#,###}}) that is included in gross income. Ellis also has $[a(4)] of income from the dividend, which he also includes in gross income [See Reg. §1.61-9(c).].

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
c. Ellis bought [a(2)] shares of XYZ stock for $[a(6)] per share on August 20. Ellis received the $[a(4)] dividend on September 10. Ellis still owns the shares at year-end.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: c. Ellis owns the XYZ shares on the record date, and received the $[a(12)] dividend. Hence, Ellis is taxed on the entire dividend. [See Reg. §1.61-9(c).]

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

Although Hank is retired, he is an excellent handyman and often works part time on small projects for neighbors and friends. Last week his neighbor, Mike, offered to pay Hank $500 for minor repairs to his house. Hank completed the repairs in December of this year. Hank uses the cash method of accounting and is a calendar-year taxpayer. Compute Hank’s gross income for this year from each of the following alternative transactions:

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_e1084b38_13570164582811567
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-e1084b38" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/e1084b38/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=arpeggio&disablebranding=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
a. Mike paid Hank $200 in cash in December of this year and promised to pay the remaining $300 with interest in three months.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: a. $200 this year.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_e1084b38_13570164582811584_1
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-e1084b38" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/e1084b38/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=arpeggio&disablebranding=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
b. Mike gave Hank tickets in December to the big game in January. The tickets have a face value of $50, but Hank could sell them for $400. Hank went to the game with his son.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. $400 this year. The value of the tickets was $400 when Hank received them.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_e1084b38_13570164582811611_2
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-e1084b38" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/e1084b38/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=arpeggio&disablebranding=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
c. Mike bought Hank a new set of snow tires. The tires typically sell for $500, but Mike bought them on sale for $450.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: c. $450. This is the fair market value of the tires at the time Mike transferred them to Hank.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

Jim recently joined the Austin Barter Club, an organization that facilitates the exchange of services between its members. This year Jim provided lawn-mowing services to other club members. Jim received the following from the barter club. Determine the amount, if any, Jim should include in his gross income in each of the following situations: (Leave no answers blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_c59dd459_13570164582811540_2
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-c59dd459" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/c59dd459/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=arpeggio&disablebranding=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
a. Jim received $275 of car repair services from another member of the club.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: a. In an exchange of services, income has been received in the amount of the value of services received (gross income includes the receipt of services as well as money and goods). Hence, Jim is taxed on the $275 of car repair services.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_c59dd459_13570164582811519
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-c59dd459" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/c59dd459/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=arpeggio&disablebranding=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
b. Jim received a $550 credit that gave him the option of receiving a season pass at a local ski resort from another member of the club. However, he forgot to request the pass by the end of the ski season and his credit expired.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. The issue is whether the "credit" represents a valuable right. Because the right could be redeemed for property worth $550, then under constructive receipt Jim should recognize income of $550.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_c59dd459_13570164582811533_1
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-c59dd459" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/c59dd459/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=arpeggio&disablebranding=0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen="" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
c. Jim received a $450 credit that can only be applied for goods or services from club members next year.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: c. If a barter credit can only be redeemed for future services, then the taxpayer could argue that no realization has yet occurred. But, it would be included in his gross income next year when the credit becomes a valuable right.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Louis files as a single taxpayer. In April of this year he received a $900 refund of state income taxes that he paid last year.

 

How much of the refund, if any, must Louis include in gross income under the following independent scenarios? Assume the standard deduction last year was $12,200. (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_45d34abc_13570164582811588_2
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-45d34abc" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/45d34abc/?f=1&player=arpeggio&secret=14205634&make_responsive=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
a. Last year Louis claimed itemized deductions of $12,450. Louis’s itemized deductions included state income taxes paid of $1,750 and no other state or local taxes.


       __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Louis received a tax benefit for the lesser of the refund ($900) or the excess of the itemized deductions above the standard deduction ($12,450 − $12,200 = $250). Hence, Louis must include $250 of the $900 refund in gross income.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_45d34abc_13570164582811574_1
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-45d34abc" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/45d34abc/?f=1&player=arpeggio&secret=14205634&make_responsive=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
b. Last year Louis had itemized deductions of $10,800 and he chose to claim the standard deduction. Louis’s itemized deductions included state income taxes paid of $1,750 and no other state or local taxes.


       __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Because he didn’t itemize his deductions, Louis received no tax benefit from the $900 tax overpayment. Hence, none of the refund is included in his gross income.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_45d34abc_13570164582811505
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-45d34abc" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/45d34abc/?f=1&player=arpeggio&secret=14205634&make_responsive=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
c. Last year Louis claimed itemized deductions of $13,640. Louis’s itemized deductions included state income taxes paid of $2,750 and no other state or local taxes.

 
       __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

 

Louis received a tax benefit for the lesser of the refund ($900) or the excess of the itemized deductions above the standard deduction ($13,640 − $12,200 = $1,440). Hence, Louis must include the entire $900 refund in gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

L. A. and Paula file as married taxpayers. In August of this year, they received a $5,200 refund of state income taxes that they paid last year.

 

How much of the refund, if any, must L. A. and Paula include in gross income under the following independent scenarios? Assume the standard deduction last year was $24,400. (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_7e6af2f6_13570164582811594_1
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-7e6af2f6" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/7e6af2f6/?f=1&player=arpeggio&secret=69467292&make_responsive=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
a. Last year L. A. and Paula had itemized deductions of $19,200, and they chose to claim the standard deduction.

 

        __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Because they did not itemize their deductions, L. A. and Paula received no benefit from the $5,200 tax overpayment. Hence, none of the refund is included in gross income.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_7e6af2f6_13570164582811502
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-7e6af2f6" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/7e6af2f6/?f=1&player=arpeggio&secret=69467292&make_responsive=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
b. Last year L. A. and Paula claimed itemized deductions of $30,700. Their itemized deductions included state income taxes paid of $7,500 and no other state or local taxes.

 

       __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

 

L. A. and Paula received a tax benefit for the lesser of the refund ($5,200) or the excess of the itemized deductions above the standard deduction ($30,700 − $24,400 = $6,300). Hence, they must include the entire $5,200 refund in gross income.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_7e6af2f6_13570164582811620_2
external_media_item.html: <iframe allowfullscreen="" id="viddler-7e6af2f6" scrolling="no" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/7e6af2f6/?f=1&player=arpeggio&secret=69467292&make_responsive=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
c. Last year L. A. and Paula claimed itemized deductions of $26,900. Their itemized deductions included state income taxes paid of $10,500, which were limited to $10,000 due to the cap on state and local tax deductions.

 

       __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

 

L. A. and Paula did not receive a tax benefit for the $500 state taxes refunded that previously were not deducted because of the $10,000 state and local tax deduction limit ($10,500 state incomes taxes paid less $10,000 state tax deduction = $500 taxes which produced no tax benefit previously). Thus, L. A. and Paula received a tax benefit for the lesser of the $5,200 refund minus the $500 state taxes previously not deducted (i.e., $5,200 − $500 = $4,700) or the excess of the itemized deductions above the standard deduction ($26,900 − $24,400 = $2,500). Hence, they must include $2,500 of the $5,200 refund in gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Clyde is a cash-method taxpayer who reports on a calendar-year basis. This year Paylate Corporation has decided to pay Clyde a year-end bonus of $1,000.

Determine the amount Clyde should include in his gross income this year under the following circumstances: (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
a. Paylate Corporation wrote the check and put it in his office mail slot on December 30 of this year, but Clyde did not bother to stop by the office to pick it up until after year-end.


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a. 

Clyde is taxed on the $1,000 under the constructive receipt doctrine.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
b. Paylate Corporation mistakenly wrote the check for $100. Clyde received the remaining $900 after year-end.

 


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b. 

Clyde is taxed on the $100 – the remaining $900 is taxed in the next year.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
c. Paylate Corporation mailed the check to Clyde before the end of the year (and it was delivered before year-end). Although Clyde expected the bonus payment, he decided not to collect his mail until after year-end.

 


    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

Clyde is taxed on $1,000 unless the mail was not delivered until after year-end. Clyde would need to check his mail on December 31 or he would have the burden of proving he didn’t receive the check before year-end if the IRS alleges that the check was delivered before year-end.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-01 Apply the concept of realization.

worksheet.stem:
d. Clyde picked up the check in December, but the check could not be cashed immediately because it was postdated January 10.


    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.

Clyde is not taxed until next year because the postdated check is a substantial restriction.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Identify the amount, if any, that these individuals must include in gross income in the following independent cases. Assume that the individuals use the cash method of accounting and report income on a calendar-year basis.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. Elmer was an extremely diligent employee this year, and his employer gave him three additional days off with pay (Elmer’s gross pay for the three days totaled $1,200, but his net pay was only $948).

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Elmer should include in gross income the $1,200 gross pay he received for the three days he was not required to work but still received compensation.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. Amax purchased new office furniture and allowed each employee to take home old office furniture valued at $250.


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Amax employees should include the value of the furniture ($250) in gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

Ralph owns a building that he is trying to lease. Ralph is a calendar-year, cash-method taxpayer and is trying to evaluate the tax consequences of three different lease arrangements. Under lease 1, the building rents for $500 per month, payable on the first of the next month, and the tenant must make a $500 security deposit that is refunded at the end of the lease. Under lease 2, the building rents for $5,500 per year, payable at the time the lease is signed, but no security deposit is required. Under lease 3, the building rents for $500 per month, payable at the beginning of each month, and the tenant must pay a security deposit of $1,000 that is to be applied toward the rent for the last two months of the lease. (Leave no answers blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. What amounts are included in Ralph’s gross income this year if a tenant signs lease 1 on December 1 and makes timely payments under that lease?

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: a. Under Kansas City Southern Industries ((1992), 98 TC 242) gross income does not include security deposits that must be returned to the taxpayer. Hence, Ralph does not include any of these payments in gross income this year. Moreover, the first rent payment is not included in his gross income this year because Ralph is a cash-method taxpayer and he does not receive the payment until next year.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. What amounts are included in Ralph’s gross income this year if the tenant signs lease 2 on December 31 and makes timely payments under that lease?

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. Ralph must include the entire $5,500 this year.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
c. What amounts are included in Ralph’s gross income this year if the tenant signs lease 3 on November 30 and makes timely payments under that lease?

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: c. Ralph must include both the rent paid ($500) and the security deposit ($1,000) in his gross income this year. Because the deposit can be applied toward rent it is treated as prepaid rent. Under Reg. §1.61-8(b) prepayments of rent are included in gross income regardless of the accounting method employed by the taxpayer. Because he is a cash-basis taxpayer, Ralph must include the rental payments he receives in gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Anne purchased an annuity from an insurance company that promised to pay her $20,000 per year for the next 10 years. Anne paid $145,000 for the annuity, and in exchange she will receive $200,000 over the term of the annuity.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_42eee32a_13570164370609861
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-42eee32a" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/42eee32a/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=full&disablebranding=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
a. How much of the first $20,000 payment should Anne include in gross income? (Do not round intermediate calculations.)

 


    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

$5,500. A part of each payment represents a return of the original $145,000 investment, and the remainder ($55,000) is income. The original investment ($145,000) is 72.5 percent of the expected value ($145,000 / $200,000). Hence, $14,500 of each payment is a return of capital (72.5 percent × $20,000), and the remaining $5,500 is income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_42eee32a_13570164370609877_1
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-42eee32a" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/42eee32a/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=full&disablebranding=0" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
b. How much income will Anne recognize over the term of the annuity?


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

 

Since Anne paid $145,000 for total payments of $200,000, she will recognize a total of $55,000 over the ten-year term of the lease.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Larry purchased an annuity from an insurance company that promises to pay him $1,500 per month for the rest of his life. Larry paid $170,820 for the annuity. Larry is in good health and is 72 years old. Larry received the first annuity payment of $1,500 this month. Use the expected number of payments in Exhibit 5-1 for this problem.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_86282abd_13570164370609814_1
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-86282abd" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/86282abd/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=simple&disablebranding=0" width="694" frameborder="0" height="520"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
a. How much of the first payment should Larry include in gross income?


    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

A part of each payment represents a return of the original $170,820 investment but to calculate the income you need the expected amount. The expected amount is calculated using the expected return multiple for Larry’s age group (14.6 for a 72 year-old). Each $1,500 monthly payment is composed of $975 of return of capital and $525 of taxable income computed as follows:

 

       
Expected return multiple   14.6  
Number of annual payments   12  
Amount of payment $ 1,500  
Expected total payment (14.6 × 12 × $1,500) $ 262,800  
Return of capital percent ($170,820 / $262,800)   65 %
Return of capital per payment ($1,500 × 65%) $ 975  
Gross income per payment ($1,500 − $975) $ 525

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_86282abd_13570164370609825
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-86282abd" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/86282abd/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=simple&disablebranding=0" width="694" frameborder="0" height="520"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
b. If Larry lives more than 15 years after purchasing the annuity, how much of each additional payment should he include in gross income?


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Because Larry has received all of his original investment as a return of capital by the end of year 15, the entire $1,500 monthly payment is included in gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_86282abd_13570164370609829_2
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-86282abd" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/86282abd/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=simple&disablebranding=0" width="694" frameborder="0" height="520"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
c. What are the tax consequences if Larry dies just after he receives the 100th payment?


    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

 

Because Larry has only recognized $97,500 as a return of his original investment (100 × $975), his executor will be entitled to deduct the remaining $73,320 ($170,820 − $97,500) on Larry’s final tax return as an itemized deduction.

worksheet.stem:
c. What are the tax consequences if Larry dies just after he receives the 100th payment?

    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

Because Larry has only recognized ${{[z(11)]:#,###}} as a return of his original investment (100 × ${{[z(5)]:#,###}}), his executor will be entitled to deduct the remaining ${{[z(12)]:#,###}} (${{[z(2)]:#,###}} − ${{[z(11)]:#,###}}) on Larry’s final tax return as an itemized deduction.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
Gramps purchased a joint survivor annuity that pays $500 monthly over his remaining life and that of his wife, Gram. Gramps is 70 years old and Gram is 65 years old. Gramps paid $97,020 for the contract. How much income will Gramps recognize on the first payment?


    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: This joint survivor annuity has an annual return multiple of 23.1 from Table VI in Reg. Sec 1.72-9. The expected return of $138,600 is calculated by multiplying the annual payment of $6,000 ($500 × 12) times the return multiple of 23.1. Hence, 70 percent of each payment ($97,020 / $138,600) will be a return of capital and 30 percent will be income. Thus, the first payment will consist of $150 ($500 × 30% = $150) of income.

internal_category.title: Topic: Realization and Recognition of Income
Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

Gramps purchased a joint survivor annuity that pays ${{[a(1)]:#,###}} monthly over his remaining life and that of his wife, Gram. Gramps is 70 years old and Gram is 65 years old. Gramps paid ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} for the contract. How much income will Gramps recognize on the first payment?

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: This joint survivor annuity has an annual return multiple of [a(3)] from Table VI in Reg. Sec 1.72-9. The expected return of ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} is calculated by multiplying the annual payment of ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} × 12) times the return multiple of [a(3)]. Hence, [a(6)] percent of each payment (${{[a(2)]:#,###}} / ${{[a(5)]:#,###}}) will be a return of capital and [a(7)] percent will be income. Thus, the first payment will consist of $[a(8)] (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} × [a(7)]% = $[a(8)]) of income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Lanny and Shirley divorced in 2018 and do not live together. Shirley has custody of their child, Art, and Lanny pays Shirley $22,000 per year. All property was divided equally.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. How much should Shirley include in income if Lanny’s payments are made in cash but will cease if Shirley dies or remarries?

 


    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

$22,000 is includible in Shirley’s gross income as alimony. The payments do not continue after Shirley’s death. It is not important that the payments may cease earlier than Shirley’s death.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. How much should Shirley include in income if $12,000 of Lanny’s payments is designated as “nonalimony” in the divorce decree?


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

 

$10,000 is includible in Shirley’s gross income as alimony. Amounts designated as “nonalimony” in the divorce or written separation agreement are not treated as alimony for tax purposes.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
c. How much should Shirley include in income if Lanny’s payments drop to $15,000 once Art reaches the age of 18?


    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

$15,000 is includible in Shirley’s gross income as alimony. The additional $7,000 in payments is treated as child support because these payments cease upon the happening of a specific contingency related to the child.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

For each of the following independent situations, indicate the amount the taxpayer must include in gross income: (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. Phil won $500 in the scratch-off state lottery. There is no state income tax.


      __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

All $500 is economic income realized this year and is, therefore, included in gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. Ted won a compact car worth $17,000 in a TV game show. Ted plans to sell the car next year.


       __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

The value of the car, $17,000, is economic income realized this year and is, therefore, included in gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
c. Al Bore won the Nobel Peace Prize of $500,000 this year. Rather than take the prize, Al designated that the entire award should go to Weatherhead Charity, a tax-exempt organization.


      __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

The entire award is excluded and therefore tax exempt. The award is excluded because it was for scientific, literary, or charitable achievement, and the taxpayer immediately transferred the award to a qualified charity.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
d. Jerry was awarded $2,500 from his employer, Acme Toons, when he was selected most handsome employee for Valentine’s Day this year.


    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.

All $2,500 is economic income realized this year and is, therefore, included in gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
e. Ellen won a $1,000 cash prize in a school essay contest. The school is a tax-exempt entity, and Ellen plans to use the funds for her college education.

 


      __new5__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
e.

All $1,000 is economic income realized this year and is, therefore, included in gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
f. Gene won $400 in the office March Madness pool.

 

      __new6__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
f.

Gene should include $400 in his gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Grady received $8,200 of Social Security benefits this year. Grady also reported salary and interest income this year.

What amount of the benefits must Grady include in his gross income under the following five independent situations? (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. Grady files single and reports salary of $12,100 and interest income of $250.


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Grady excludes the entire $8,200 because the sum of his modified AGI plus 50 percent of his Social Security benefits ($12,100 + $250 + $4,100 (50% of Social Security benefits) = $16,450) is below the minimum amount ($25,000 or less for single taxpayers) for including Social Security benefits.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. Grady files single and reports salary of $22,000 and interest income of $600.


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

$850. Grady is single and his modified AGI plus 50 percent of his Social Security benefits ($22,000 + $600 + $4,100 (50% of Social Security benefits) = $26,700) falls between $25,000 and $34,000. His taxable Social Security benefits are the lesser of (a) 50 percent of the Social Security benefits ($8,200 × 50% = $4,100) or (b) 50 percent of [$22,600 modified AGI + $4,100 (50 percent of Social Security benefits) − $25,000] = $850). Thus, his taxable Social Security benefits are $850.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
c. Grady files married joint and reports salary of $75,000 and interest income of $500.


      __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

Grady includes 85 percent of the benefits or $6,970 ($8,200 × 85 percent) because his modified AGI is well above the maximum amount ($44,000 for married joint) for including Social Security benefits.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
d. Grady files married joint and reports salary of $44,000 and interest income of $700.


    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.

$6,970. Grady files married joint and his modified AGI plus 50 percent of his Social Security benefits ($44,000 + $700 + $4,100 (50% of Social Security benefits) = $48,800) exceeds $44,000. His taxable Social Security benefits are the lesser of (a) 85 percent of Social Security benefits (85% × $8,200 = $6,970) or (b) 85 percent of [$44,700 modified AGI + $4,100 (50% of Social Security benefits) − $44,000] = $4,080), plus the lesser of (1) $6,000 or (2) 50 percent of Social Security benefits ($4,100). This simplifies to the lesser of $6,970 or $8,180 ($4,080 + $4,100). Thus, his taxable Social Security benefits are $6,970.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
e. Grady files married separate and reports salary of $22,000 and interest income of $600.

 


    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
e.

$6,970. Because Grady files married separate, his taxable Social Security benefits are the lesser of (a) 85 percent of the Social Security benefits (85% × $8,200 = $6,970) or (b) 85 percent of the taxpayer's modified AGI plus 50 percent of his Social Security benefits (85% × ($22,000 + $600 + $4,100 (50% of Social Security benefits) = $22,695). Thus, his taxable Social Security benefits are $6,970.

worksheet.stem:
e. Grady files married separate and reports salary of ${{[a(10)]:#,###}} and interest income of ${{[a(11)]:#,###}}.

 


    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:

${{[a(22)]:#,###}}. Thus, his taxable Social Security benefits are ${{[a(32)]:#,###}}.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

George and Weezy received $30,200 of Social Security benefits this year ($12,000 for George; $18,200 for Weezy). They also received $5,000 of interest from jointly owned City of Ranburne Bonds and dividend income.

What amount of the Social Security benefits must George and Weezy include in their gross income under the following independent situations? (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. George and Weezy file married joint and receive $8,000 of dividend income from stocks owned by George.


    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

George and Weezy exclude the entire $30,200 of Social Security benefits because the sum of their modified AGI plus 50 percent of their Social Security benefits ($5,000 + $8,000 + $15,100 (50% of Social Security benefits) = $28,100) is below the minimum amount ($32,000 or less for taxpayers filing married joint) for including Social Security benefits.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. George and Weezy file married separate and receive $8,000 of dividend income from stocks owned by George.


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

$10,200 for George and $9,860 for Weezy. Because George files married separate, he must include in gross income the lesser of (a) $10,200 (85% of his $12,000 Social Security benefits) or (b) $14,025 (85% of his modified AGI + 50% of his Social Security benefits = 85% × [$2,500 interest + $8,000 dividends + 50% × ($12,000)] = 85% x ($16,500) = $14,025). Because Weezy files married separate, she must include in gross income the lesser of (a) $15,470 (85% of her $18,200 Social Security benefits) or (b) $9,860 (85% of the sum of her modified AGI + 50% of her Social Security Benefits = 85% × [$2,500 interest + 50% x ($18,200)] = 85% x ($11,600) = $9,860).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
c. George and Weezy file married joint and receive $30,000 of dividend income from stocks owned by George.


    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

$11,185. Because George and Weezy file married joint and their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits ($5,000 interest + $30,000 dividends + (50% ($30,200)) = $50,100) exceeds $44,000, they must include in gross income the lesser of (a) 85 percent of their Social Security benefits (85% ($30,200) = $25,670), (b) 85 percent of (their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits - $44,000 = ($5,000 interest + $30,000 dividends + 50% ($30,200) − $44,000) = $6,100), plus the lesser of (1) $6,000 or (2) 50 percent of Social Security benefits (50% ($30,200) = $15,100). Thus, they must include in income the lesser of (a) $25,670 or (b) 85 percent of $6,100 ($5,185), plus the lesser of (1) $6,000 or (2) $15,100, which simplifies to $11,185.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
d. George and Weezy file married joint and receive $15,000 of dividend income from stocks owned by George.


    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.

$1,550. Because George and Weezy file married joint and their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits ($5,000 interest + $15,000 dividends + (50% ($30,200)) = $35,100) falls between $32,000 and $44,000, they must include in gross income the lesser of (a) 50 percent of their Social Security benefits (50% ($30,200) = $15,100), (b) 50 percent of (their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits − $32,000) = ($5,000 interest + $15,000 dividends + (50% ($30,200) − $32,000) = $3,100). Thus, they must include in income the lesser of (a) $15,100 or (b) 50 percent of $3,100 ($1,550).

c.
${{[z(28)]:#,###}}. Because George and Weezy file married joint and their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits (${{[z(4)]:#,###}} interest + ${{[z(6)]:#,###}} dividends + (50% (${{[z(1)]:#,###}})) = ${{[z(21)]:#,###}}) exceeds ${{[z(24)]:#,###}}, they must include in gross income the lesser of (a) 85 percent of their Social Security benefits (85% (${{[z(1)]:#,###}}) = ${{[z(22)]:#,###}}), (b) 85 percent of (their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits − ${{[z(24)]:#,###}} = (${{[z(4)]:#,###}} interest + ${{[z(6)]:#,###}} dividends + 50% (${{[z(1)]:#,###}}) − ${{[z(24)]:#,###}}) = ${{[z(23)]:#,###}}), plus the lesser of (1) ${{[z(25)]:#,###}} or (2) 50 percent of Social Security benefits (50% (${{[z(1)]:#,###}}) = ${{[z(26)]:#,###}}). Thus, they must include in income the lesser of (a) ${{[z(22)]:#,###}} or (b) 85 percent of ${{[z(23)]:#,###}} ({{[z(27)]:#,###}}), plus the lesser of (1) ${{[z(25)]:#,###}} or (2) ${{[z(26)]:#,###}}, which simplifies to ${{[z(28)]:#,###}}.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
d. George and Weezy file married joint and receive ${{[z(7)]:#,###}} of dividend income from stocks owned by George.


    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.
${{[z(32)]:#,###}}. Because George and Weezy file married joint and their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits (${{[z(4)]:#,###}} interest + ${{[z(7)]:#,###}} dividends + (50% (${{[z(1)]:#,###}})) = ${{[z(30)]:#,###}}) falls between ${{[z(10)]:#,###}} and ${{[z(24)]:#,###}}, they must include in gross income the lesser of (a) 50 percent of their Social Security benefits (50% (${{[z(1)]:#,###}}) = ${{[z(26)]:#,###}}), (b) 50 percent of (their modified AGI + 50% of their Social Security benefits − ${{[z(10)]:#,###}}) = (${{[z(4)]:#,###}} interest + ${{[z(7)]:#,###}} dividends + (50% (${{[z(1)]:#,###}}) − ${{[z(10)]:#,###}}) = ${{[z(31)]:#,###}}). Thus, they must include in income the lesser of (a) ${{[z(9)]:#,###}} or (b) 50 percent of ${{[z(31)]:#,###}} ({{[z(33)]:#,###}}).

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Nikki works for the Shine Company, a retailer of upscale jewelry. How much taxable income does Nikki recognize under the following scenarios? (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. Nikki buys a diamond ring from Shine Company for $10,000 (normal sales price, $14,000; Shine Company’s gross profit percentage is 40 percent).


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Because Nikki’s 28.57% discount ([$14,000 – $10,000] / $14,000) is less than Shine Company’s gross profit percentage, the bargain purchase from her employer does not result in taxable income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. Nikki receives a 25 percent discount on jewelry restoration services offered by Shine Company. This year, Nikki had Shine Company repair a set of antique earrings (normal repair cost $500; discounted price $375).


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Nikki will recognize $25 of taxable income from the discounted services provided by Shine Company. Discounts more than 20% for services are taxable. Thus, Nikki’s taxable discount is $25 ($125 Discount received − (20% × $500) = $25).

    __new2__

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Wally is employed as an executive with Pay More Incorporated. To entice Wally to work for Pay More, the corporation loaned him $20,000 at the beginning of the year at a simple interest rate of 1 percent. Wally would have paid interest of $2,400 this year if the interest rate on the loan had been set at the prevailing federal interest rate.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
a. Wally used the funds as a down payment on a speedboat and repaid the $20,000 loan (including $200 of interest) at year-end.

 

Does this loan result in any income to either party?
  

__new1__

 

Indicate the amount below.

 

  __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Pay More has actual interest income of $200 and imputed interest income of $2,200 (the market amount of interest on the loan). (Note that Pay More will also be entitled to a compensation deduction of $2,200). Wally has compensation income from the loan of $2,200, the amount of the imputed interest. The imputed interest expense is not deductible because he used the loan proceeds for personal purposes.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-02 Discuss the distinctions between the various sources of income, including income from services and property.

worksheet.stem:
b. Assume instead that Pay More forgave the loan and interest on December 31. What amount of gross income does Wally recognize this year?


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Wally must include $2,200 in gross income from the discounted interest rate he received on the loan ($2,400 interest at federal rate minus $200 he actually was required to pay). Also, Wally must include the $20,000 in gross income because Pay More forgave the $20,000 loan, and he must include $200 in gross income because Pay More forgave the $200 interest Wally owed.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Jimmy has fallen on hard times recently. Last year he borrowed $250,000 and added an additional $50,000 of his own funds to purchase $300,000 of undeveloped real estate. This year the value of the real estate dropped dramatically, and Jimmy’s lender agreed to reduce the loan amount to $230,000.

 

For each of the following independent situations, indicate the amount Jimmy must include in gross income: (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. The real estate is worth $175,000 and Jimmy has no other assets or liabilities.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Jimmy recognizes no income. The loan reduction generates $20,000 of income from discharge of indebtedness, but Jimmy can exclude this income because he is insolvent even after the discharge (assets of $175,000 versus liabilities of $230,000).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. The real estate is worth $235,000 and Jimmy has no other assets or liabilities.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Jimmy recognizes $5,000 of income. The loan reduction generates $20,000 of income from discharge of indebtedness, but Jimmy can only exclude $15,000 of this income because he becomes solvent after this amount of discharge (assets of $235,000 versus liabilities of $230,000).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c. The real estate is worth $200,000 and Jimmy has $45,000 in other assets but no other liabilities.


__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

Jimmy recognizes $15,000 of income. The loan reduction generates $20,000 of income from discharge of indebtedness, and Jimmy is insolvent before the cancellation of indebtedness (assets of $245,000 versus liabilities of $250,000) but he is solvent by $15,000 after the cancellation of debt ($245,000 assets and $230,000 of debt).

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

Fred currently earns $9,000 per month. Fred has been offered the chance to transfer for three to five years to an overseas affiliate. His employer is willing to pay Fred $10,000 per month if he accepts the assignment. Assume that the maximum foreign-earned income exclusion for next year is $107,600.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a-1. How much U.S. gross income will Fred report if he accepts the assignment abroad on January 1 of next year and works overseas for the entire year?

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a-1.

Fred will earn $120,000 by going abroad, but he can exclude $107,600 under the foreign earned income exclusion. Hence, Fred will report gross income of $12,400 from the salary earned.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a-2. If Fred’s employer also provides him free housing abroad (cost of $20,000), how much of the $20,000 is excludable from Fred’s income?

      __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a-2.

Since Fred meets the requirements for the foreign-earned income exclusion, he may also exclude the employer-provided housing costs that exceed $17,216 (16% x $107,600), up to a maximum exclusion of $15,064 (14% x $107,600). Thus, Fred may exclude $2,784 (the lesser of (a) ($20,000 housing cost less $17,216 = $2,784) or (b) $15,064). Thus, Fred includes $17,216 ($20,000 - $2,784 exclusion) of the employer-provided housing in gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. Suppose that Fred's employer has offered Fred a six-month overseas assignment beginning on January 1 of next year. How much U.S. gross income will Fred report next year if he accepts the six-month assignment abroad and returns home on July 1 of next year?

    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Fred will earn $60,000 during the first half of the year and $54,000 during the second half of the year. However, because he is not physically abroad for 330 days during a consecutive 12-month period (and he would not have a foreign tax home), Fred will not be able to claim any foreign earned income exclusion. So, he will report $114,000 of gross income next year.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c-1. Suppose that Fred’s employer offers Fred a permanent overseas assignment beginning on March 1 of next year. How much U.S. gross income will Fred report next year if he accepts the permanent assignment abroad? Assume that Fred will be abroad for 305 days out of 365 days next year. (Do not round intermediate calculations. Round your final answer to the nearest whole dollar amount.)

       __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c-1.

Fred will earn $18,000 during January-February and $100,000 during the remainder of the year.  However, he will be able to claim a partial exclusion of $89,912 based upon his time abroad [$107,600 full exclusion x 305 / 365 (days in foreign country/days in year)]. Thus, Fred will report gross income of $28,088 ($118,000 − 89,912). Note that Fred will be abroad the requisite 330 days during a consecutive 12-month period beginning in March.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c-2. If Fred’s employer also provides him free housing abroad (cost of $16,000 next year), how much of the $16,000 is excludable from Fred’s income? Assume that Fred will be abroad for 305 days out of 365 days next year. (Use 365 days in a year. Do not round intermediate calculations. Round your final answer to the nearest whole dollar amount.)

       __new5__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c-2.

Since Fred is not abroad the entire year, the foreign housing exclusion is also reduced. To be excluded, the costs must exceed $14,386 ($107,600 × 305/365 × 16%), with a maximum exclusion of $12,588 ($107,600 × 305/365 × 14%). Thus, Fred may exclude the lesser of (a) $1,614 ($16,000 housing cost less $14,386 = $1,614) or (b) $12,588. Thus, Fred includes $14,386 ($16,000 − $1,614) of the employer-provided housing in gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

For each of the following situations, indicate how much the taxpayer is required to include in gross income: (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. Steve was awarded a $5,000 scholarship to attend State Law School. The scholarship pays Steve's tuition and fees.

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

The $5,000 scholarship is excluded from gross income because it is used to pay Steve's tuition and fees.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. Hal was awarded a $15,000 scholarship to attend State Hotel School. All scholarship students must work 20 hours per week at the School residency during the term.

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

The $15,000 scholarship is included in gross income because the terms of the scholarship require Hal to perform services.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Cecil cashed in a Series EE savings bond with a redemption value of $14,000 and an original cost of $9,800.

For each of the following independent scenarios, calculate the amount of interest Cecil will include in his gross income assuming he files as a single taxpayer: (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. Cecil plans to spend all of the proceeds to pay his son’s tuition at State University. Cecil’s son is a full-time student, and Cecil claims his son as a dependent. Cecil estimates his modified adjusted gross income at $63,100.

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

Cecil will report no Series EE interest in gross income. All of the $4,200 of interest income ($14,000 − $9,800) is eligible for exclusion because Cecil is using all the proceeds for a qualified purpose. All of the eligible interest is excluded because Cecil’s modified gross income is below the 2020 threshold for the phase-out of the exclusion ($82,350).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. Assume the same facts in part (a), except Cecil plans to spend $4,200 of the proceeds to pay his son’s tuition at State University, and Cecil estimates his modified adjusted gross income at $60,600.

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

 

Cecil will report $2,940 of Series EE interest in gross income. Cecil is eligible to exclude $1,260 or 30 percent of the $4,200 of interest income because he is only using 30 percent of the proceeds for a qualified purpose ($4,200 / $14,000). Cecil is not required to phase-out the amount of the exclusion because his modified gross income is below the threshold for the phase out of the exclusion.

worksheet.stem:
b. Assume the same facts in part (a), except Cecil plans to spend ${{[z(5)]:#,###}} of the proceeds to pay his son’s tuition at State University, and Cecil estimates his modified adjusted gross income at ${{[z(4)]:#,###}}.


    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Cecil will report ${{[z(9)]:#,###}} of Series EE interest in gross income. Cecil is eligible to exclude ${{[z(11)]:#,###}} or 30 percent of the ${{[z(7)]:#,###}} of interest income because he is only using 30 percent of the proceeds for a qualified purpose (${{[z(7)]:#,###}} / ${{[z(1)]:#,###}}). Cecil is not required to phase-out the amount of the exclusion because his modified gross income is below the threshold for the phase out of the exclusion.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Grady is a member of a large family and received the following payments this year. For each payment, determine whether the payment constitutes realized income and determine the amount of each payment Grady must include in his gross income. (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. A gift of $20,000 from Grady’s grandfather.

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

The gift is realized income that is entirely excluded from gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. One thousand shares of GM stock worth $120 per share inherited from Grady’s uncle. The uncle purchased the shares for $25 each, and the shares are worth $125 at year-end.

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Inheritances are realized income but are entirely excluded from gross income. The increase in the value of the shares during the year has not yet been realized.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c. A gift of $50,000 of Ford Motor Bonds. Grady received the bonds on October 31, and he received $1,500 of semiannual interest from the bonds on December 31.

 

__new3__

__new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

The gift of the bonds is realized income that is entirely excluded from gross income. The interest accrued up to October 31st is excluded because it was accrued at the time of the gift. Hence, the accrued income was part of the gift. Grady is taxed on $500 of interest that accrued after the date of the gift (he is taxed on it when he receives it).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
d. A loan of $5,000 for school expenses from Grady’s aunt.

    __new5__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.

A bona fide loan is not realized income. If the loan is actually a disguised gift, the gift would be realized income but the value is excluded from gross income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Bart is the favorite nephew of his aunt Thelma. Thelma transferred several items of value to Bart. For each of the following transactions, determine the effect on Bart’s gross income. (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. Thelma gave Bart an auto worth $22,000. Thelma purchased the auto three years ago for $17,000.

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

$0. The value of the auto is excluded from Bart’s gross income (Note that Bart will take a tax basis of $17,000 in the auto).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. Thelma elects to cancel her life insurance policy, and she gives the cash surrender value of $15,000 to Bart.

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

$0. The gift of cash is excluded from Bart’s gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c. Bart is the beneficiary of a $100,000 whole life insurance policy on the life of Thelma. Thelma died this year, and Bart received $100,000 in cash.

    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

$0. All $100,000 of insurance proceeds are excluded.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
d. Bart inherited 500 shares of stock from Thelma’s estate. Thelma purchased the shares many years ago for $1,200, and the shares are worth $45,000 at her death.

    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.

$0. The value of the shares ($45,000) is excluded from Bart’s income (Note that Bart will take a tax basis of $45,000 in the shares). The increase in value has not been realized.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

Terry was ill for three months and missed work during this period. During his illness, Terry received $4,500 in sick pay from a disability insurance policy. What amounts are included in Terry’s gross income under the following independent circumstances? (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_4552d8a7_13570164370609815
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-4552d8a7" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/4552d8a7/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=simple&disablebranding=0" width="694" frameborder="0" height="520"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
a. Terry has disability insurance provided by his employer as a nontaxable fringe benefit. Terry’s employer paid $2,800 in disability premiums for Terry this year.

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

$4,500. The disability pay of $4,500 is included in Terry’s gross income because Terry’s employer paid the insurance premiums as a nontaxable fringe benefit to Terry. Consequently, the disability insurance premiums of $2,800 paid by Terry’s employer are excluded from Terry’s gross income.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_4552d8a7_13570164370609879_3
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-4552d8a7" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/4552d8a7/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=simple&disablebranding=0" width="694" frameborder="0" height="520"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
b. Terry paid $2,800 in premiums for his disability insurance this year.

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

$0. The disability pay of $4,500 is excluded from Terry’s gross income because Terry paid the insurance premiums. Note: the cost of disability insurance premiums is not deductible as a medical expense.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_4552d8a7_13570164370609867_2
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-4552d8a7" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/4552d8a7/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=simple&disablebranding=0" width="694" frameborder="0" height="520"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
c. Terry’s employer paid the $2,800 in premiums for Terry, but Terry elected to have his employer include the $2,800 as compensation on Terry’s W-2.

    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

$0. Even though his employer paid the premium, the premium is taxable compensation to Terry, so he is treated as though he paid the premiums. Thus, the answer is the same as for part b.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

external_media_item.title: _viddler_4552d8a7_13570164370609856_1
external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-4552d8a7" src="http://www.viddler.com/embed/4552d8a7/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=simple&disablebranding=0" width="694" frameborder="0" height="520"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
d. Terry has disability insurance whose cost is shared with his employer. Terry’s employer paid $1,800 in disability premiums for Terry this year as a nontaxable fringe benefit, and Terry paid the remaining $1,000 of premiums from his after-tax salary. (Do not round intermediate calculations. Round your answer to the nearest whole dollar amount.)
    
    __new4__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
d.

 

$2,893. A portion of the disability pay is excluded from Terry’s gross income because Terry paid a portion of the insurance premiums. Terry can exclude $1,607 = [($1,000 / $2,800) × $4,500].

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

What amounts are included in gross income for the following taxpayers? (Leave no answers blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. Janus sued Tiny Toys for personal injuries from swallowing a toy. Janus was paid $30,000 for medical costs and $250,000 for punitive damages.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: a. The $30,000 is excluded from Janus’s gross income because it is a payment for a physical injury. However, the $250,000 of punitive damages is included in Janus’s gross income because the payment is intended to punish Tiny Toys rather than compensate Janus for her injuries.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. Carl was injured in a car accident. Carl’s insurance paid him $50,000 to reimburse his medical expenses and an additional $25,000 for the emotional distress Carl suffered as a result of the accident.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: b. The reimbursed medical costs and the payment for emotional distress associated with a physical injury are excluded.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c. Ajax published a story about Pete, and as a result Pete sued Ajax for damage to his reputation. Ajax lost in court and paid Pete an award of $20,000.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: c. Pete must include the payments in gross income because the payments are not associated with a physical injury.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
d. Bevis was laid off from his job last month. This month he drew $800 in unemployment benefits.

 

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: d. Bevis must include the unemployment benefits in his gross income because unemployment benefits are a replacement for lost wages.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

This year, Janelle received $200,000 in life insurance proceeds. Under the following scenarios, how much of the $200,000 is taxable? (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. Janelle received the proceeds upon the death of her father, Julio.

    __new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

None of the $200,000 is taxable as life insurance proceeds are generally not taxable for income tax purposes. The $200,000 proceeds, however, would be included in her father’s estate, and thus, may be subject to estate tax.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. Janelle received the $200,000 proceeds because she was diagnosed with colon cancer (life expectancy of six months), and she needed the proceeds for her care.

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

 

None. Because Janelle was medically certified as terminally ill with an illness expected to cause death within 24 months.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c. The proceeds related to a life insurance policy she purchased for $35,000 from a friend in need. After purchase, Janelle paid annual premiums that total $22,000.

    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

 

$143,000. Because Janelle purchased the life insurance policy from a friend for valuable consideration, she may exclude the $200,000 proceeds up to the sum of the purchase price of the policy ($35,000) and any subsequent premiums ($22,000) with the remaining proceeds ($200,000 − $35,000 − $22,000 = $143,000) taxable as ordinary income.

sectionBreak.stem:
[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

 

This year, Leron and Sheena sold their home for $750,000 after all selling costs. Under the following scenarios, how much taxable gain does the home sale generate for Leron and Sheena? (Leave no answer blank. Enter zero if applicable.)

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
a. Leron and Sheena bought the home three years ago for $150,000 and lived in the home until it sold.
 

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

$100,000. Because Leron and Sheena satisfy the 2-year ownership and 2-year use test, they may exclude up to $500,000 of gain from the sale of their home. Thus, Leron and Sheena may exclude $500,000 of the $600,000 gain ($750,000 − $150,000 = $600,000 realized gain) that they realized on the sale.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
b. Leron and Sheena bought the home one year ago for $600,000 and lived in the home until it sold.

    __new2__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Because Leron and Sheena do not satisfy the 2-year ownership or 2-year use test, the entire $150,000 realized gain ($750,000 - $600,000 = $150,000) is taxable.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c. Leron and Sheena bought the home five years ago for $500,000. They lived in the home for three years until they decided to buy a smaller home. Their home has been vacant for the past two years.

    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.

Despite not living in the house the past 2 years, Leron and Sheena still meet the 2-year ownership and 2-year use tests, and therefore, they may exclude up to $500,000 gain on the sale. Thus Leron and Sheen may exclude the entire $250,000 gain realized on the sale ($750,000 − $500,000 = $250,000 realized gain).

[The following information applies to the questions displayed below.]

worksheet.commonFeedback:
b.

Because Leron and Sheena do not satisfy the 2-year ownership or 2-year use test, the entire ${{[z(8)]:#,###}} realized gain (${{[z(1)]:#,###}} − ${{[z(3)]:#,###}} = ${{[z(8)]:#,###}}) is taxable.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

worksheet.stem:
c. Leron and Sheena bought the home five years ago for ${{[z(4)]:#,###}}. They lived in the home for three years until they decided to buy a smaller home. Their home has been vacant for the past two years.

    __new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
c.
Despite not living in the house the past 2 years, Leron and Sheena still meet the 2-year ownership and 2-year use tests, and therefore, they may exclude up to ${{[z(6)]:#,###}} gain on the sale. Thus Leron and Sheen may exclude the entire ${{[z(9)]:#,###}} gain realized on the sale (${{[z(1)]:#,###}} − ${{[z(4)]:#,###}} = ${{[z(9)]:#,###}} realized gain).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.

external_media_item.html: <iframe id="viddler-1b47680d" src="https://www.viddler.com/embed/1b47680d/?f=1&autoplay=0&player=arpeggio&disablebranding=0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen="" width="694" height="520" frameborder="0"></iframe>

worksheet.stem:
Dontae’s employer has offered him the following employment package.

 

     
Salary $ 400,000
Health insurance   10,000
Dental insurance   1,500
Membership to Heflin Country Club   20,000
Season tickets to Atlanta Braves games   5,000
Tuition reimbursement for graduate courses   4,000
Housing allowance (for a McMansion in his neighborhood of choice)   40,000

 

What is Dontae’s gross income from his employment?

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback: $465,000. Dontae’s $400,000 salary + $20,000 club membership + $5,000 season tickets + $40,000 housing allowance are included in his gross income. The health insurance and dental insurance is an excludable benefit under §106, and the tuition reimbursement is excludable under §127.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 05-03 Apply basic income exclusion provisions to compute gross income.
